content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <origin>U.S. Geological Survey / The Nature Conservancy</origin> <pubdate>2009</pubdate> <title>African Surficial Lithology</title> <edition>v1.0</edition> <geoform>raster digital data</geoform> <onlink><http://rmgsc.cr.usgs.gov/ecosystems/index.shtml></onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>The African surficial lithology dataset is a map of parent materials - a mix of bedrock geology and unconsolidated surficial materials classes. The goal was to produce a map that reflected the key geological parent materials which act as primary determinants in the distribution of African vegetation /ecosystems. It is a compilation and reclassification of twelve digital geology, soil and lithology databases. Nineteen surficial lithology classes were delineated in Africa based on geology, soil and landform. Whenever available, multiple sources of ancillary digital data, hard copy maps and literature were reviewed to assist in the reclassification of the source data to the African surficial lithology classification. Of particular note, due to the varying spatial and classification resolutions of the geologic source data, the African surficial lithology map varies in spatial complexity and classification detail across Africa.</abstract> <purpose>The African surficial lithology data was developed as a primary input dataset for an African Ecological Footprint mapping project undertaken by the U.S. Geological Survey and The Nature Conservancy. The project used a biophysical stratification approach which was based on mapping the major structural components of ecosystems (land surface forms, lithology, isobioclimates and biogeographic regions). These unique physical components, which are considered as the fundamental building blocks of ecosystems, were reviewed by regional vegetation and landscape ecology experts and used in a classification and regression tree (CART) inductive model to map intermediate scale African ecosystems.</purpose> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>2009</caldate> </sngdate> </timeinfo> Arlington and Reston, Virginia.</datacred> <native>ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.0.1770</native> <crossref> <citeinfo> <origin>Sayre, R., P. Comer, H. Warner and J. Cress.</origin> <pubdate>2008</pubdate> <title>A New Map of Standardized Terrestrial Ecosystems of the Coterminus United States</title> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Reston, Virginia</pubplace> <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish> </pubinfo> </citeinfo> </crossref> </idinfo> <dataqual> <attracc> <attraccr>Of particular note, due to the varying spatial and classification resolutions of the geologic source data, the African surficial lithology map varies in spatial and classification resolution across Africa. That is, it is a continental dataset with a 90 meter pixel resolution, but some regions (e.g. Kenya) have more spatial complexity/classification detail than other regions (e.g. Morocco).</attraccr> </attracc> <logic>See Attribute Accuracy Report</logic> <complete>The study area for the African terrestrial ecological footprint mapping project includes all of continental Africa, plus various nearby island nations (i.e. Canary Islands, Cabo Verde, Sao Tome and Principe, Saint Helena, Prince Edward Islands, Madagascar, Isles Eparses, Comores, Seychelles, Reunion, and Mauritius). The African surficial lithology map reflects this geographic extent. The geographic extent of some of the source datasets actually overlaps (i.e. FAO Africover covers Tanzania and the South African SOTER covers Tanzania). In developing the African surficial lithology dataset, in all cases of overlap, the source data with the finer spatial resolution was merged on top of the coarser scale data.</complete> <lineage> Geology map</srccitea> <srccontr>One of twelve digital geology, soil and lithology databases that were compiled and reclassified to develop the African Surficial Lithology dataset.</srccontr> </srcinfo> <procstep> <procdesc>For each of the twelve geologic source datasets, the geologic rock type and a variety of supplementary attribute information (e.g. soils, landforms, parent materials, etc.) were extensively reviewed to identify the most appropriate reclassification to the African surficial lithology classification. Whenever available, ancillary data sources (e.g. digital datasets (WWF HydroSHEDS, DEMs, etc.), digital jpeg images of hard copy geology/soil maps and online literature) were also reviewed to assist in the reclassification.</procdesc> <procdate>200903</procdate> </procstep> <procstep> <procdesc> Each of the twelve reclassified source datasets was then resampled to a 90 meter pixel resolution grid, merged together in the following order (FAO Africover, South African SOTER, Central African SOTER, Senegal SOTER, Madagascar geology map, Northeastern African SOTER and GDS Geology map), expanded by approximately 10 kilometers, and then aligned/masked to the USGS African coastline boundary. See the project report for more detailed information about processing of the African surficial lithology dataset (Bow, J., M. Brown and R. Sayre. 2009. African Terrestrial Ecological Footprint Mapping Project. The Nature Conservancy and U.S. Geological Survey. Arlington and Reston, Virginia). </procdesc> <procdate>200903</procdate> </procstep> </lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <direct>Raster</direct> <rastinfo> <rasttype>Grid Cell</rasttype> <rowcount>101430</rowcount> <colcount>106637</colcount> <vrtcount>1</vrtcount> </rastinfo> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <geograph> <latres>0.000833</latres> <longres>0.000833</longres> <geogunit>Decimal degrees</geogunit> </geograph> <geodetic> <horizdn>D_WGS_1984</horizdn> <ellips>WGS_1984</ellips> <semiaxis>6378137.000000</semiaxis> <denflat>298.257224</denflat> </geodetic> </horizsys> </spref> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>lithology.vat</enttypl> <enttypd>Unknown</enttypd> <enttypds>ESRI</enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>Rowid</attrlabl> <attrdef>Internal feature number.</attrdef> <attrdefs>ESRI</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>VALUE</attrlabl> <attrdef>A unique numeric grid value representing a surficial lithology class</attrdef> <attrdefs>Unkown</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>0</edomv> <edomvd>Unknown</edomvd> <edomvds>unknown</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>1</edomv> <edomvd>Carbonate</edomvd> <edomvds>Sedimentary/metasedimentary rock; generally porus and generally >6 pH (e.g. limestone, dolomite, marl, other carbonate rocks, dolomitic marbles, shale, dinosaur fossils, fossilferous)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>2</edomv> <edomvd>Karst</edomvd> <edomvds>A subset of class 1, but where karst processes are at or just below the surface, ancillary information was used to identify karst regions.</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>3</edomv> <edomvd>Non-Carbonate</edomvd> <edomvds>Sedimentary rock; generally porous, and generally <6 pH (e.g. clastic sedimentary rock, sandstone, siltstone, greywacke, arkose, conglomerate, siltstone, mudstone, claystone, ironstone, tillite, coal, quartzarenite)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>4</edomv> <edomvd>Metasedimentary</edomvd> <edomvds>Metamorphic sedimentary rock (e.g. slate, phylitte, quartzite, metapelitic, paragneiss, metabasalt, metapeliti, metavolcanics, metasediments, greenstone belts)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>5</edomv> <edomvd>Alkaline Intrusive Volcanic</edomvd> <edomvds>Basic/mafic intrusive igenous rock; generally non-porous, and generally >6 pH (e.g. basic (mafic) igenous rock, dolerite, gabbro, syenite, anorthosite, dunite, norite, diorite-syenite)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>6</edomv> <edomvd>Silicic</edomvd> <edomvds>Acid intrusive igenous rock, including most/all granites and non-alkaline intrusive volcanics, generally non-porous, and generally < 6 pH (e.g. acid (felsic) igneous rock, granite, quartz-diorite, granodiorite, intermediate igenous, includes all undifferentiated intrusive rocks)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>7</edomv> <edomvd>Metaigneous</edomvd> <edomvds>Metamorphic igneous rock (e.g. granitoids, alkali feldspar, granulite, quartz diorite, charckonite, including all undifferentiated metamorphic rock)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>8</edomv> <edomvd>Ultramafic</edomvd> <edomvds>All intrusive and extrusive ultrabasic volcanic rocks (>10 pH) (e.g. periodotite, pyroxenite, gabbro, chromitite, komatite, serpentine)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>9</edomv> <edomvd>Extrusive Volcanic</edomvd> <edomvds>All acidic and basic (mafic) extrusive volcanic rocks; generally porous? (e.g. basalt, andesite, trachyte, phonolite, auguite, nephelinite, carbonatite, rhyolite, latite, dacite, volcanic breccia, tholeitic flood basalt, quartz porphyry, tonalite)</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>10</edomv> <edomvd>Colluvium</edomvd> <edomvds>Colluvial, mass movement, colluvial and alluvial</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>11</edomv> <edomvd>Hydric - Organic</edomvd> <edomvds>Organic parent material (e.g. swamp, marsh).</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>12</edomv> <edomvd>Aeolian Sediments</edomvd> <edomvds>Sand dune, eolian</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>13</edomv> <edomvd>Alluvium - Fan Deposits</edomvd> <edomvds>A spatially distinct fan type alluvial geologic feature; mixed texture</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>14</edomv> <edomvd>Alluvium - Fluvial</edomvd> <edomvds>A spatially distinct linear type hydrologic alluvial geologic feature; mixed texture</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>15</edomv> <edomvd>Alluvium - Beach, Strand, Coastal Dune</edomvd> <edomvds>A spatially distinct coastal type alluvial geological feature. Often includes aeolian sediments/sand dune.</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>16</edomv> <edomvd>Alluvium - Saline</edomvd> <edomvds>Salt flat/pan, solonchak or sodic solonetz soils; lacustrine, playas, sabkha</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>17</edomv> <edomvd>Alluvium - Gypsum</edomvd> <edomvds>Gypsiferous sand, gypsum pan</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>18</edomv> <edomvd>Alluvium - Other</edomvd> <edomvds>Mixed unconsolidated or semi-consolidated sand, gravel, silt, clay, etc.</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>19</edomv> <edomvd>Volcanic Ash, Tuff, Mudfow</edomvd> <edomvds>Unconsolidated complexes of volcanic ash, lahar, ignimbrite, pumice, and pyroclastic rocks</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>20</edomv> <edomvd>Water</edomvd> <edomvds>unknown</edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>COUNT</attrlabl> <attrdef>The total number of pixels assigned to each surficial lithology class (grid value)</attrdef> <attrdefs>unknown</attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>unknown</udom> </attrdomv> </attr> </detailed> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntorgp> <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey</cntorg> <cntper>Jill Cress</cntper> </cntorgp> <cntaddr> <addrtype>Mailing</addrtype> <address>US Geological Survey, Geosciences and Environmental Change Science Center, Box 25046, MS 980</address> <city>Lakewood</city> <state>Colorado</state> <postal>80225</postal> <country>USA</country> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>303-236-1248</cntvoice> </cntinfo> </distrib> <resdesc>Downloadable Data</resdesc> <distliab> The data you have secured from the USGS database identified as "African Surficial Lithology" have not received Director's approval and as such are provisional and subject to revision.
